moves.10. Na4: Not only to blockade the pawn but to penetrate into the holes in White's queenside. 10. Bb5 is most often played here.
moves.10... Nd7: Black wants to play 11...b6, but his pieces become awkwardly placed in the queenside.
moves.11. O-O-O b6: His problem is how to develop the light-squared bishop.
moves.12. Bb5: White already has a strong initiative.
moves.12... Bb7: Better would have been 12...Qc7 13. Qf2 Rb8. Then White could have chosen between tightening his grip on the queen file by 14. Rd3 and Rhd1 later or initiating a Kingside pawn-storm with 14. h4 and 15. g4. But now the b-pawn is lost.
moves.13. Qf2 Nc5: At least, he is able to dispatch one of the knights.
moves.14. Naxc5 bxc5 15. Nxc5 Qc7 16. Na4: White must keep this knight because it is destined for great things.
moves.16... Ba6 17. Bxc6: White sees correctly that it is of more value to exchange Black's knight rather than his light-squared bishop which will remain inert at the sides.
moves.17... Qxc6 18. Nb6 Rab8 19. Rd2: To tighten the grip on the d-file.
moves.19... Rb7: Black concentrates on his own half-open file.
moves.20... Rfb8 21. Nd5 Bd8: Disdains the exchange of the bishop, but 21...Bf8 was preferable.
moves.22. Rhd1 a4 23. b4 Ba5: Intent on the attack, he has left his King to his own devices.
moves.24. Nf6+:
The Sudden Stroke! quite unexpected to Black. Aside from the text, I also looked at 24. Ba7 which also wins against all defences:
A. 24...Rxb4 25. Nxb4 (25. Bxb8 Rb7 <to protect against 26. Ne7 > 26. Ba7 Qb5 27. Bb6 Bxb6 28. Nxb6 Rxb6 29. Qxb6 Qxb6 30. Rxd6 Qxd6 31. Rxd6) 25...Rxb4 (25...Bxb4 26. Bxb8 Bxd2  27. Qxd2  -) 26. Rxd6 Qc8 27. Bb6 Bxb6 28. Qxb6 wins.
B. 24...Bxb4 25. Ne7  (25. Nxb4 Rxb4 26. Bxb8 Qb5 would not do for White) 25...Rxe7 (25...Kf8 26. Nxc6 <26. Bxb8 Qc3> 26...Bc3 27. Bb6 <27. Nxb8 Bb2  draws> 27...Rxb6 28 Qxb6 Rxb6 29. Rxd6 Bb2  30. Kd2) 
26. Bxb8 Bxd2  27. Qxd2 wins
C. 24...Ra8 (or 24...Rc8) 25. bxa5 Qb5 26. Bb6 and the file is neutralized.

But the text is not only prettier it is the most direct way to expose the most crucial aspect of the position.
moves.24... Kh8:
There was also:
A. 24...gxf6 25. Bh6 Kh8 26. Qg3 (necessary to draw the rook away from the b-file) 26...Rg8 27. Qh4 d5 (27...Rg6 28. Rxd6) 28. Rxd5
Now, a. 28...Bc7 (or 28...Bxb4) 29. Rd6; 
         b. 28...Bd8 29. Rxd8
         c. 28...Rg6 29. Rd8  Bxd8 30. Rxd8  Rg8 31. Qg3
         d. 28...Rc7 (threatening mate) 29. Rc5 Qe6 30. Rxa5 Bb7 31. b5 wins
         e. 28...Qe6 29. bxa5; if 29...Rc8 30. Rd6 Qe7 31. Rd7 Qe6 32. R1d6. 
                           Or if 29...Bb7 30. Rd8 Rb8 31. Qg3;
                           And if 29...f5 30. Rd6
B. 24...Kf8 25. Rxd6 Qb5 26. Bc5 Re7 27. Rd7 (or 27. Nd7  Ke8 28. Nxb8 wins material) 27...gxf6 (27...Bxb4 28. Rd8 ) 28. Rxe7 Kg7 29. Qg3  Kh8 (29...Kf8 loses the queen, while 29...Kh6 30. Be3  Kh5 31. Qg4#) 30. Rxf7 Rg8 31. Rf8 Rxf8 32. Bxf8 Qb7 33. bxa5  wins
